components.html: This is a step where authors can enter their own html. Authors can also embed images and videos.

components.prompt: This is a step where students enter text.

This is an auto-graded step that will give the student an automated score and automated text feedback. (Note: the auto graded functionality only works in a run and does not work when simply previewing the project)

Explain how the sun helps animals survive.
This is similar to an open response step but the text entry area opens in a popup so that students can still see the content from the previous step.

This is a multiple choice step where the student is allowed to choose one choice.

Who lives in a pineapple under the sea?

choices.feedback: Patrick doesn't live in a pineapple, he lives under a rock
Squidward doesn't live in a pineapple, he lives in an Easter island head

components.prompt:
This is a multiple choice step where the student is allowed to choose multiple choices.

Which of these are Ninja Turtles?

choices.feedback: Great Job you know your Ninja Turtles
Great Job you know your Ninja Turtles
Great Job you know your Ninja Turtles
Great Job you know your Ninja Turtles

components.prompt:
This is a multiple choice step that the student must answer correctly before they can move forward in the project. If the student gets the question wrong, they must go back to Step 1.1 in order to attempt the step again. This type of step is used to get students to review content when they get the question wrong.

Bulbasaur is what type of Pokemon?

choices.feedback: Sorry, Bulbasaur is not a fire type Pokemon.
Sorry, Bulbasaur is not a water type Pokemon.

components.prompt:
This is a step where students must drag and drop choices into the appropriate bucket.

Match the controllers with the appropriate console. Then click the 'Submit Answer' button at the bottom of the page to check your answer.

Authors can require the choices to be placed in a specific order within a bucket. Place the Playstation console images into the Playstation History bucket in the order of oldest to newest. Then click the 'Submit Answer' button at the bottom of the page to check your answer.

components.html: This is a step where students must answer a series of questions that are either text or mulitple choice questions. This step is set up so that the student must answer all the questions before they can move to any other step. Once the student submits their answer, they can no longer change their answer. These restrictions can be turned on or off for this step type.

components.prompt: What is your favorite type of food?
What is your favorite type of chocolate?
What is your favorite movie?
Edit prompt here
This is a draw step where the student can draw a diagram.
This draw component imports work from the draw component above.
This draw component imports work from the draw component above.
This draw component imports work from the draw component above.

This is an auto graded draw step. Click the 'Submit' button to have your drawing auto graded.

 

(1) Use stamps to create TWO methane molecules (CH4). 

(2) Create EXACTLY the number of oxygen molecules (O2) needed to react with your TWO methane molecules.

(3) Create a new frame.

(4) REARRANGE the atoms in the 2nd frame to make carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) molecules. Show clearly which atoms belong to which molecules.

This is a forum discussion type of step where students can post their response and then see their classmates' responses. (Note: the brainstorm step only works in a run and does not work when simply previewing the project)

This is a table step where students fill out a table. You can make certain cells editable and other cells uneditable so the student can't change them. You can also allow the student to add/delete columns as well as add/delete rows.

The table step can be authored to allow the student to graph the table data. Here is an example of using the table data to create a line graph. I have authored the step to pre-populate the table data so all you need to do is click "Make Graph".
Enter prompt here
components.title: Enter graph title here

components.prompt: Here is an example of a bar graph.
Here is an example of a pie graph.
Label the picture.
The work you enter for this step will be displayed at the top of the next step.
You should see your work from the previous step at the top of this step. The previous step and this step do not need to be the same type of step.
The work from this step will be imported into the next step.
Your work from the previous step should be entered into the text area below. This feature works best if the previous step and this step are the same type of step.

Authors can create constraints to control student navigation. For these constraint examples, I will be using open response steps but the constraints can be used with other step types as well. This step has been authored so that the student must complete the step before they can move forward. They are allowed to move backwards though.
This step has been authored so that the student can't leave the step until they have completed it.

Do not enter any work for this step. Try to move to the next step "Must Complete Previous Step 2", you should not be able to. Try to move to the step after the next step "Must Complete Previous Step 3", you should be able to. This feature is used to make the student complete a specific step before they can work on another specific step. Now enter some work for this step and click save. You should then be able to move to the next step.
Good job, you completed "Must Complete Previous Step 1".

components.html: Now go back to "Must Complete Previous Step 1".

components.prompt:
The answers for this step will be aggregated for the whole class and displayed in the next step. (Note: the aggregating of class data only works in a run and does not work when simply previewing the project). The answer for this step will also determine which branch path you are assigned to in the Branching Point step.

What is your favorite type of chocolate?
You should see a pie graph with the aggregate student data for the class above. Actually, you won't see anything here. Just go to the next step.

components.html: You chose "Dark" in the multiple choice step. Enjoy your dark chocolate!
You chose "Milk" in the multiple choice step. Enjoy your milk chocolate!
You chose "White" in the multiple choice step. Enjoy your white chocolate!
You have been randomly assigned to a path based on your workgroup id. The next step will be the first step in the branch path.
You have reached the step where the paths merge back together.

components.prompt: There is a ladder that leads up, a door that leads forward, and a rope that leads down. Which one do you choose?
You climb the ladder up to the roof. The sun's rays burn you to death.
You step out of the door and find ice cream. It is delicious. Yum.
You climb down the rope and fall into outer space. You float through space until you run into the Battlestar Galactica. You kill everyone on the ship because the show sucks.

Game Over.
Now work on the Planning Activity.
Good job, you completed the Planning Activity.
Stay
Mind

GREENROOF-II

5 points
The plants get the light energy from the sun and transform the energy to a new kind of energy called chemical energy. Also carbon dioxide, water, and the light energy come together and make the plants food, a sugar named glucose. They say that glucose is so energy rich because the light energy that was turned into chemical energy can be stored int the glucose for later and thats why these people have plants growing on there roof.

4 points
The energy comes from the sun and the energy transfers from place to place by bouncing off one another. The energy goes into the plant and is stored and is stored as chemical energy. Energy changes from light energy to chemical energy by the other energy's together..

3 points
energy comes from pre-existing energy that transforms, energy is stored in molecules. Energy explodes and the chemicals inside change.

2 points
it would lower the energy use because it goes t the plants before it gets to the building

1 point
hello

components.prompt:
GREENROOF-II

5 points
The plants get the light energy from the sun and transform the energy to a new kind of energy called chemical energy. Also carbon dioxide, water, and the light energy come together and make the plants food, a sugar named glucose. They say that glucose is so energy rich because the light energy that was turned into chemical energy can be stored int the glucose for later and that's why these people have plants growing on their roof.

4 points
The energy comes from the sun and the energy transfers from place to place by bouncing off one another. The energy goes into the plant and is stored and is stored as chemical energy. Energy changes from light energy to chemical energy by the other energy's together.

3 points
Energy comes from pre-existing energy that transforms, energy is stored in molecules. Energy explodes and the chemicals inside change.

2 points
It would lower the energy use because it goes to the plants before it gets to the building.

1 point
Hello

5 points

Also carbon dioxide, water, and the light energy come together and make the plants food, a sugar named glucose. They say that glucose is so energy rich because the light energy that was turned into chemical energy can be stored int the glucose for later and that's why these people have plants growing on their roof.

4 points

multipleAttemptScoringRules.feedbackText: Good progress. Now add information. How will plants lower the houses energy use? Think about what happens to sunlight that hits the side of the roof with NO plants? Check out Step 2.3 for a hint. Then, add to your explanation below.

You are on the right track. Add details. Contrast what happens to light energy when it hits a dark roof to when light energy hits the plants. Hint: Slow down the model in Step 2.3 and watch a few sunrays. Then, add to your explanation below.

Great job! Now think about this. If Brent and Emilios house was in a shady spot where it did not get much sunlight, what would be a better approach to reduce energy use...grow plants on the roof or not? Add to your explanation below.
Nice work. You are a superstar!
TALK TO YOUR TEACHER to help you take your answer further. The top bar of your screen is now red so your teacher knows to come talk to you.
